results.title: 5 Places to Bask in Spectacular Foliage This Fall
results.abstract: It was a summer of heat, droughts and deluges. Experts say that stress could make autumn colors especially vivid. Here’s where you can savor them before they’re gone.

media.caption: The brilliant mountain maples, birches and beeches in the White Mountains of New Hampshire are expected to peak starting at the end of this month.

results.abstract: With the “cheese slice trick” and the “egg crack challenge,” parents vie for viral recognition — and the illusion of control over their children.

results.title: In a Blow to Russia, Ukraine Says It Killed Chief of Black Sea Fleet
results.abstract: As they ramp up attacks on occupied Crimea, Ukrainian forces are repeatedly targeting the fleet based there, a key to Russia’s attacks deep into Ukraine and its blockade of Ukrainian ports.

results.title: Finland Raced to Join NATO. What Happens Next Is Complicated.
results.abstract: After decades of going it alone in security issues, Finns are finding that life in a large alliance is complex, expensive and deeply political.

media.caption: Finnish soldiers participating in a military exercise in Rovajarvi, Finland, in May. Finland joined the NATO alliance in April of this year, ending decades of military nonalignment.

results.title: Meet the Climate-Defying Fruits and Vegetables in Your Future
results.abstract: Hot-weather cherries, drought-resistant melons and six other crops in the works that could change how we eat in a fast-warming world.

results.title: David McCallum, Heartthrob Spy of ‘The Man From U.N.C.L.E.,’ Dies at 90
results.abstract: An experienced character actor, he found fame in the 1960s as the enigmatic Illya Kuryakin, and again in the 2000s as an eccentric medical examiner on “N.C.I.S.”

media.caption: David McCallum as Illya Kuryakin on “The Man From U.N.C.L.E.” His part was originally meant to be small, but he soon became a fixture of the series — and, somewhat to his annoyance, a sex symbol.

results.abstract: In one divorce announcement after another, high-profile couples are abiding by the golden rule of the schoolyard: If you can’t say something nice, don’t say anything at all.

results.title: Mammals’ Time on Earth Is Half Over, Scientists Predict
results.abstract: A new model suggests that in 250 million years, all land will collide into a supercontinent that boosts warming and pushes mammals to extinction.

media.caption: Sunset in Aluksne, Latvia, during a heat wave in August 2022.

results.title: Ancient Arrow Is Among Artifacts to Emerge From Norway’s Melting Ice
results.abstract: As the earth warms, glacial archaeologists are in a race against time to preserve objects before they are destroyed by the elements. Recent field work yielded a surprisingly intact 3,000-year-old arrow.

media.caption: A wooden arrow about 3,000 years old and in unusually fine condition was found in the mountains of Norway this month.

results.title: The Wrecking-Ball Caucus: How the Far Right Brought Washington to Its Knees
results.abstract: Right-wing Republicans who represent a minority in their party and in Congress have succeeded in sowing mass dysfunction, spoiling for a shutdown, an impeachment and a House coup.

media.caption: Representative Bob Good of Virginia, one of the Republican rebels, said he had had just one constituent express concern about a government shutdown.

results.title: Money for Ukraine at Center of Senate Bid to Avert Shutdown

results.title: How a Little-Known Group Helped Resurgent Democrats Wield Power
results.abstract: For decades, Republicans have had a far more robust network of conservative policy groups to push their legislative agenda. Now the States Project is aiming to fill that void on the left.

media.caption: Joanna E. McClinton, the Democratic speaker of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives, said the States Project was “filling a vacuum” on the left.
